name: Pollinator Basics
insight: Pollinators are responsible for helping many plants reproduce by moving pollen between flowers.
tip: Supporting pollinators helps maintain healthy ecosystems and food systems.

name: Native Plants Matter
insight: Native plants evolved alongside local pollinators and meet their needs better than exotic species.
tip: Choose native plants whenever possible to provide reliable food sources.

name: Bees and Flowers
insight: Bees are attracted to flowers with strong scents and bright colors.
tip: Plant clusters of flowers instead of single plants to make foraging easier.

name: Winter Habitat
insight: Many pollinators overwinter in leaf litter, hollow stems, or soil.
tip: Leave fallen leaves and plant stems undisturbed during colder months.

name: Water Sources
insight: Pollinators need water just like other wildlife.
tip: Provide a shallow water dish with stones for safe drinking.

name: Avoid Chemicals
insight: Chemical pesticides can harm pollinators even at low doses.
tip: Use natural pest control methods to protect pollinator health.

name: Soil Health
insight: Healthy soil supports stronger plants that provide better nectar and pollen.
tip: Add compost to enrich soil naturally.

name: Diversity Matters
insight: Different pollinators prefer different plant species.
tip: Plant a variety of flowers to support a wide range of pollinators.

name: Early Bloomers
insight: Early-blooming plants are vital for pollinators emerging in spring.
tip: Include early bloomers like crocus or wildflowers in your garden.

name: Late Season Blooms
insight: Pollinators need food sources late into the season.
tip: Plant fall-blooming flowers to extend food availability.

name: Sunny Spaces
insight: Most pollinators prefer warm, sunny areas.
tip: Plant pollinator gardens in sunny locations when possible.

name: Shelter Matters
insight: Pollinators need shelter from wind and rain.
tip: Include shrubs or tall grasses to create protective cover.

name: Small Spaces Count
insight: Even small gardens or balconies can support pollinators.
tip: Use containers with flowering plants if space is limited.

name: Color Preferences
insight: Different pollinators are drawn to different colors.
tip: Plant a mix of blue, purple, yellow, and white flowers.

name: Fragrance Signals
insight: Many pollinators rely on scent to locate flowers.
tip: Choose fragrant plants to attract more visitors.

name: Plant in Groups
insight: Grouped plants are easier for pollinators to find.
tip: Plant flowers in clusters instead of scattering them.

name: Avoid Double Blooms
insight: Double-flowered varieties often lack accessible nectar.
tip: Choose single-flower varieties for better pollinator access.

name: Local Seeds
insight: Locally sourced seeds are adapted to your climate.
tip: Buy seeds from local or regional suppliers when possible.

name: Windbreaks
insight: Strong winds can make feeding difficult for pollinators.
tip: Use fences or shrubs to reduce wind exposure.

name: Natural Mulch
insight: Organic mulch improves soil health and moisture retention.
tip: Use leaves or wood chips instead of synthetic mulch.

name: Observation
insight: Watching pollinators helps you understand their needs.
tip: Spend time observing which plants attract the most activity.

name: Patience Pays
insight: Pollinator gardens improve over time as plants mature.
tip: Give your garden time to establish before making changes.

name: Reduce Lawn Space
insight: Lawns provide little value to pollinators.
tip: Replace portions of lawn with flowering plants.

name: Healthy Ecosystems
insight: Pollinators are indicators of ecosystem health.
tip: Supporting pollinators benefits the entire environment.

name: Seasonal Planning
insight: Planning ahead ensures blooms throughout the year.
tip: Create a planting plan that spans multiple seasons.

name: Minimal Disturbance
insight: Frequent disturbance can disrupt pollinator habitats.
tip: Limit excessive pruning and soil disruption.

name: Community Impact
insight: Pollinator-friendly spaces add up across neighborhoods.
tip: Encourage others to plant pollinator gardens.

name: Educational Value
insight: Pollinator gardens provide learning opportunities for all ages.
tip: Use your garden as a way to teach others about sustainability.

name: Long-Term Care
insight: Consistency is key to maintaining pollinator habitats.
tip: Maintain your garden year after year for lasting impact.

name: Every Action Counts
insight: Small actions can collectively make a big difference.
tip: Even one plant can help support pollinators.
